“Crime and Punishment”

“Please sit down,” he said suddenly. “I want to talk to you. I know you’re probably in a rush, but can you spare me two minutes?” He pulled out a chair for her.

Sonia sat down again, glancing nervously at the two ladies before looking down. Raskolnikov’s pale face turned red, and he felt a shiver run through him as his eyes lit up.

“Mother,” he said firmly, “this is Sofya Semyonovna Marmeladov, the daughter of that poor Mr. Marmeladov who got run over yesterday right in front of me. I was just telling you about him.”

Pulcheria Alexandrovna looked at Sonia, narrowing her eyes slightly. Even though she felt awkward under Rodya’s intense gaze, she couldn’t help but feel a bit satisfied. Dounia stared seriously at Sonia’s face, trying to figure her out. When Sonia heard her name, she tried to meet their eyes again but felt even more embarrassed.

“I wanted to ask you,” Raskolnikov said quickly, “how everything went down yesterday. The police didn’t give you any trouble, right?”

“No, it was fine… the cause of death was obvious, so they didn’t bother us. It’s just that the lodgers are upset.”

“Why’s that?”

“They’re angry about the body staying here so long. It’s hot now, so today they’ll move it to the cemetery chapel until tomorrow. At first, Katerina Ivanovna was…”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov introduces Sonia, the daughter of the deceased Marmeladov, to his mother and sister while expressing concern about the funeral arrangements.
